98.pros: - Even though it's not a strong name in the tech world, it's still a good brand and can help you get noticed.- Nice environment for graduates- Travelling and paid expenses can be fun
98.cons: - Not the place to make money as a technical contributor. It will take you 6-8 years to make the same you could in 2 years working elsewhere.This is because the consulting framework is applied no matter the role you have, so although you might be promoted every two years, the pay is still significantly below market. - Your experience will depend mostly on the projects you are on, and rarely a project will have the perfect combination of interesting work, nice client/project team, and cool location. You may get the first two for example and be in the middle of nowhere. - It feels like you are constantly looking for a job. That's because you are (in most cases). You have to keep your CV always up to date, network to be recommended to projects, interview for roles, and can be rolled off your project at any time. Unless you want out of the project. In that case, it's very likely that the engagement manager/partner will hold you there for as long as possible.

271.desc: Good at consulting, so-so at coding
271.pros: Compared to the other big management consulting companies outside MBB, Deloitte takes concrete steps to build up and maintain its workers. That's work-life balance, perks, vacation, using bench time strategically, etc. So, as much as one can say this, Deloitte cares and takes action to prove it. You'll also have the opportunity to learn a lot about how to be a good consultant: understanding clients, selling and delivering work, and building up your colleagues.
271.cons: Deloitte Consulting is a good consulting company, but a mediocre tech company. There's nothing glaringly wrong, but it does not, and will not, have the right mindset to compete for technical talent. Past a certain point, the technical track dead-ends. You'll stop learning valuable skills and your compensation will level off. Your two options are up (forget how to code, manage multiple projects, build your client network, and meet annual sales goals) or out.

409.desc: You can steer your own career if you make the right connections.

Great health benefits, and they are actually hiring diverse. A lot of really smart, nice people in the consultant and senior consultant level. Nice offices, even though the coffee machines never seem to work. It's all remote and optional to go in. Travel is now only at the client's request and usually only leadership have to go.
409.cons: Upper management is super focused on selling and checking boxes for the client. Lots of smoke and mirrors to cover subpar work because invariably, there's no time in the budget to do thorough work. Work life balance sucks especially if you're doing RFP work. Sad 401k, non-existent to terrible project management, immature human-centered design practice and don't even get me started on the horrendous onboarding experience. Also, timesheets X 2– a daily one and a weekly one and some projects demand a third. Getting a computer other than the issued tiny Dell laptop was like pulling teeth, same for software to do your job. Which has to be requested for each project all over again. 541.desc: Is it even worth all the effort?
541.pros: - Good learning in each new project; you work with multiple clients, different problems, different teams ; so you end up learning and growing at very a fast pace . - leadership is supportive of your learning and growth - Encouraging messaging and direction from the CEO, Dan, who wants to provide the best talent experience. - perks of being on the road- hotel and airline points & status
541.cons: - lot of work- spend 10-15 hrs each day (more since remote work)- accountability increases as you grow in the firm, a lot of work pressure. High stress environment because of tight timelines, promising (selling) more work than available capacity (resources ) to deliver - competitive peers - impact your performance evaluation as it is relative to your peers- high expectations- client work+ pursuit support+ internal firm activity work - unreasonable leadership demands: frequently night and weekend calls; frequent requests to review and redo work since each lead (reviewer) wants to add his/her own flavor ; often there are too many people delegating and fewer people doing the heavy lifting - not only you need to deal with client politics and drama ; many times (depending on project team) there will internal politics as well - not sure if the sacrifices is worth the pay and learning (partners/ directors get paid well but it's a long tough road to reach there)- overall very stressful and draining; you need to have a thick skin, be very smart (shrewd and intelligent) , work hard and be great at communication, relationship/trust/brand building in order to thrive here.

615.desc: If you get lucky, you will be able to enjoy variety of interesting work
615.pros: If you're in a good position within your practice (you will need certain amount of luck, of course), you will be able to enjoy breadth of work; there could be opportunities to transfer to difference service lines, and you see surprising number of people who have done so. Regardless of service lines, Deloitte is a decent size player in most markets they play in, with exception to very niche services (e.g., creative services, certain advisory functions). Which means the mobility will allow you to enjoy different work experiences with reasonably similar level of market (1 - 2 tier).
615.cons: There are unspoken hierarchies among service lines ( Audit/Tax < Advisory < Consulting < Strategy Consulting ) and I honestly think it hurts morale. Cross functional collaboration can be very fun but can also be a lot of headache due to politics depending on the people. You will be expected to work long hours but that's determined by PPMDs and clients not middle management. The homegrown are paid less than transplants. So be willing to negotiate with competitor offers every couple years or so. You parents and significant other probably will not understand what you do.

729.desc: It's good if you can't get into a tech company
729.pros: Co-workers are generally nice people and won't backstab you unless you're a manager/senior manager.You will learn good soft skills which will make you more successful later.
729.cons: Take your equivalent level on levels.fyi, and divide it by 2 or 3. That's your salary at Deloitte. People squabble over 4% vs 9% raises, meanwhile the equivalent personnel at any FAANG are making 100 - 200% more (equivalent personnel being tech sales, SWE, or PM).Also, the company does not distinguish between consultants who write code and tech salespeople. These two categories of people are both considered tech consultants and there is no pay bump whatsoever if you are savvy enough to write code for the client. Guess what this results in? Most good technical resources leave to get paid fairly elsewhere and those who remain are either focusing on family or are too busy chilling to worry about getting compensated fairly. Oddly enough, there are actually people here who have great skills but somehow they are not ambitious enough to leave and double or triple their salary. It boggles my mind.That said, there is absolutely nothing wrong with this chill attitude towards life. But if you care about money even in the slightest and are passionate about working with companies that actually define the future of tech, you will not be satisfied at Deloitte. What happens is the tech industry brings out new tech (like cloud, which is very old news by now), and then 10 years later Deloitte helps bring the now-10-year-old tech to clients who are even more outdated.
729.authorInfo: Verified User Current Employee  G********  Software Engineer - Apr 30, 2021

883.desc: Plenty of learning opportunities, but poor firm leadership
883.pros: Prestige of a big 4, generous PTO, and plenty of opportunities to learn and grow professionally.  Middle management has been really great, providing me with strong guidance and direction. Ienjoy working with my managers and feel like most managers I meet are strong and capable of leadership.
883.cons: Too much work, poor compensation, benefits, and lack of proper pay gap between Senior level and first years. I am a high performer being paid 10% more than a first year because they decided to bump up first years starting salary without correcting anyone else's salary. The new starting salary increased by 10% YoY to remain competitive. Despite being a high performer and receiving above average raises every year, I'm now only making 10% more than someone who just started. Don't even get me started on the wfh meals (hint there are none). Despite working 14 hours a day to meet tight deadlines during busy season, its firm policy that we cannot expense meals at home, due to tax implications. With all these IPOs and SPACs going on, our company is thriving but our pay and benefits do not reflect that. The firm is constantly developing new technology that is worse than the technology it is intended to replace. Omnia is burning a ton of cash and doesnt even work properly. Upper management is constantly ranting and raving about how great it is and how it will increase audit efficiency. I haven't seen that and after working in it for a year, I can confidently tell you that it is a failed project. Ridden with bugs, in-optimization, and over-engineered solutions, Omnia has increased my workload and frustration levels beyond what benefits the platform could possibly provide. Firm leadership has become an echo chamber of yes men, afraid to cast their burning pile of money in a poor light. Its time to impair the value of this intangible asset.
883.authorInfo: Verified User Current Employee  S********  Audit Senior - Dec 19, 2020

932.resignation reason: Company failed to follow its own official policy when it comes to promotion or compensation. Deloitte performance review is score based, on a scale of 1-5, with 1 being highest.I worked for ~2 years, maintaining on avg. 95% utilization and received a 1 for both years. So, at the 2nd 6 month review, I requested for promotion. Management told me that barring any hiccups, I was set for promotion. At year end review, despite maintaining the same work ethic and utilization rate, my promotion was being denied because I hadn't worked long enough at the company to qualify for promotion. No where in HR documents is it explicitly or implicitly written that a resource must have x amount of years to qualify for promotion. In fact the official message from Talent was performance the only factor for promotion. I later found out that others who were up for promotion were also denied for the exact reason. In fact the MD that boomeranged from Accenture, just brought over people from Accenture to fill in for the positions we were up for. Management assured me that in lieu of promotion they would make it up to me in compensation. When it came to compensation time, I got a cost of living adjustment and no bonus. I left the company and found a job that pays 2x more in a month.
932.authorInfo: Verified User Former Employee  U*****  Solutions Analyst - Oct 31, 2020

Appraisals are good (have been so far for me atleast)4. Having an understanding and open-to-ideas manager/team lead helps to get a decent appraisal and promotion5. Internal mobility is being promoted a lot since Covid but they are (until now) limited to only few Service Lines (could be due to more growth in those Service Lines).. But if there is opening in a SL of your choice, things can move fast
947.cons: Sharing this specifically for Consulting:1. They expect you to do multiple things at the same.time and also expect u to work majorly on all weekends (barring a few may be) and won't bother to ask you if u r available to work on weekend before committing deadline to client2. They will ask u to work for 60 hrs a week but allow you to put only 20 hrs on the Timesheet!! So utilisation goes for a toss3. The coach (the one who looks after your appraisal) may not bother to speak to you except during year end appraisal cycle and more often than not is unaware of what u r working on (Coach is different from your Manager)4. The work can get monotonous for some as a lot of work is based on what Deloitte has done with other clients.. so if u worked on a Transaction Advisory project, chances are u will get more of the same kind of projects since u have experience there5. Senior managers/Directors/Partners have the habit of biting off more than they can chew so they will have crazy ongoing projects which are already understaffed but will still bid for newer projects and they will take these resources from these very (understaffed) projects n ask them to finish the Proposal in 3-4 days so they can work on the current project over the weekend!
